title: Shades of Green Color: Names, Codes, Meanings and Uses
excerpt: Green shades influence mood, design, and branding. From soft pastels to vivid emeralds, each hue carries unique meaning and practical applications across art, interior, and fashion.
content:
Green is one of the most versatile and emotionally resonant colors, spanning a spectrum from light, refreshing tones to deep, luxurious shades. From soft mints and celery greens to rich emeralds and forest hues, each shade carries its own mood and meaning. Green is often categorized by undertones—blue-greens like teal and aquamarine evoke calm and sophistication, while yellow-greens such as olive and chartreuse feel lively and organic.

Across design, fashion, and everyday life, green inspires a sense of balance, growth, and connection to nature. Its wide range allows it to be refreshing, energizing, calming, or elegant, depending on how it’s used. Whether creating a serene space, adding vibrancy to a wardrobe, or highlighting natural elements, green offers endless possibilities for expression.

Common Shades of Green

Light/Pastel Greens: Mint, Celadon, Pistachio, Seafoam, Honeydew

Bright/Vibrant Greens: Lime, Kelly Green, Chartreuse, Neon Green, Shamrock

Dark/Deep Greens: Forest Green, Emerald, Hunter Green, Bottle Green, Pine

Earth/Olive Greens: Sage, Olive, Moss Green, Army Green, Fern

Blue-Greens: Teal, Aqua, Viridian, Cyan, Turquoise

This post dives into the meanings, symbolism, and practical uses of greens, exploring how each shade influences mood, design, and culture.

Apple Green

Apple Green (#8DB600) is a bright, fresh, and slightly yellow-toned green directly named after the skin of a Granny Smith apple. Historically, it became a distinct color name with the rise of consumer goods and food marketing in the 20th century. Interestingly, this shade is strongly associated with tartness and crispness. In design, Apple Green signifies freshness, health, and vitality, making it popular for packaging, logos, and websites related to natural foods, tech startups, and spring themes.

  • HEX #8DB600
  • RGB 141, 182, 0
  • CMYK 23, 0, 100, 29

Artichoke

Artichoke (#8F9779) is a subdued, grayish-green shade inspired by the outer leaves of the artichoke vegetable. This color name entered common usage with the rise of horticultural and food-based palettes in the 19th century. Interestingly, it is considered a quintessential earth tone and is often used in military uniforms for its natural camouflage properties. Artichoke evokes a sense of organic calm, maturity, and understated elegance. Consequently, it is favored in home décor, matte paint finishes, and rustic design schemes to create a muted, natural background.

  • HEX #8F9779
  • RGB 143, 151, 121
  • CMYK 5, 0, 20, 41

Asparagus

Asparagus (#87A96B) is a soft, grayish spring green named after the edible spear of the asparagus plant. This color became popular in the late 19th century as part of a trend for naturalistic hues. Notably, it is one of the official Crayola crayon colors introduced in 1993. The shade represents fresh growth, subtlety, and early spring. As a result, Asparagus is commonly used in feminine designs, wedding stationery, and soft interior accents to convey gentle renewal.

  • HEX #87A96B
  • RGB 135, 169, 107
  • CMYK 20, 0, 37, 34

Avocado

Avocado (#568203) is a deep, yellowish-green that mimics the flesh of a ripe avocado. The color name gained prominence in the 1960s and 1970s, often associated with appliances and home décor of that era. It is a retro tone that symbolizes organic richness, fertility, and the 1970s aesthetic. Therefore, Avocado is effectively used in vintage designs, eco-branding, and natural product marketing to evoke warmth and natural abundance.

  • HEX #568203
  • RGB 86, 130, 3
  • CMYK 34, 0, 98, 49

Bamboo

Bamboo (#DEB887) is a warm, light beige with strong yellow-green undertones, named after the giant woody grass. This color connects to East Asian art and culture where bamboo symbolizes resilience and flexibility. Interestingly, it captures the color of dried, processed bamboo poles rather than the living plant. Bamboo represents natural simplicity, strength, and earthy warmth. Thus, it is widely applied in interior design for flooring and furniture, spa branding, and minimalist aesthetics to create a serene, organic environment.

  • HEX #DEB887
  • RGB 222, 184, 135
  • CMYK 0, 17, 39, 13

Basil

Basil (#6F9940) is a muted, grayish green inspired by the leaves of the popular culinary herb. This color name reflects the Victorian era’s fascination with botanical and garden-inspired hues. Interestingly, it is a sophisticated and subdued alternative to brighter greens. Basil conveys herbal freshness, tranquility, and understated taste. Consequently, it is often used in culinary branding, wellness websites, and natural paint colors to suggest organic quality and calm.

  • HEX #6F9940
  • RGB 111, 153, 64
  • CMYK 27, 0, 58, 40

Beetle Green

Beetle Green (#4A5D23) is a dark, desaturated green with brown undertones, named for the iridescent shell of certain beetles. This color draws from the naturalist observations of the 19th century. Notably, it has a camouflage-like quality and a mysterious, earthy depth. Beetle Green suggests resilience, antiquity, and the natural world. As such, it is employed in military apparel, historical recreations, and luxury packaging to impart a sense of rugged durability and heritage.

  • HEX #4A5D23
  • RGB 74, 93, 35
  • CMYK 20, 0, 62, 64

Bottle Green

Bottle Green (#006A4E) is a very dark, bluish-green traditionally associated with glass bottles, particularly wine and beer bottles from the 19th century. Historically, it was a popular color for woollen cloth and academic dress. This shade signifies traditionalism, substance, and reliability. Therefore, Bottle Green is a staple in preppy fashion, institutional branding, and traditional library interiors to convey established trust and depth.

  • HEX #006A4E
  • RGB 0, 106, 78
  • CMYK 100, 0, 26, 58

Bright Green

Bright Green (#66FF00) is an intense, highly saturated yellowish-green that is extremely luminous. It is a color of pure spectral light, often associated with digital displays and neon signs. This shade represents radiant energy, extreme vibrancy, and cyber culture. Thus, Bright Green is used for highlighter pens, safety gear, and futuristic graphics to command maximum attention and suggest technological advancement.

  • HEX #66FF00
  • RGB 102, 255, 0
  • CMYK 60, 0, 100, 0

British Racing Green

British Racing Green (#004225) is a deep, very dark green famously linked to British motorsports since the early 1900s. Its origin is tied to a racing nationality code and the shade varies from near-black to forest green. This color embodies heritage, prestige, and high performance. Consequently, it is iconic in automotive design, luxury branding, and sporting memorabilia to evoke tradition and exclusive competition.

  • HEX #004225
  • RGB 0, 66, 37
  • CMYK 100, 0, 44, 74

Brunswick Green

Brunswick Green (#1B4D3E) is a very dark, bluish-green historically used as a pigment for paints and enamels. The name originates from the Duke of Brunswick who popularized it in the 18th century. Notably, it was a standard color for railway locomotives and carriages. This shade signifies industrial strength, tradition, and dignified formality. Therefore, Brunswick Green is applied in heritage signage, official uniforms, and historic restoration projects to communicate steadfastness and authority.

  • HEX #1B4D3E
  • RGB 27, 77, 62
  • CMYK 65, 0, 19, 70

Bud Green

Bud Green (#7BB661) is a soft, yellowish-green that mimics the color of new leaf buds in spring. This color name evokes early growth and renewal. It is a gentle and optimistic shade, less intense than full leaf green. Bud Green represents youthful potential, tender beginnings, and natural cycles. Consequently, it is ideal for children’s products, garden center branding, and eco-friendly packaging to suggest new life and gentle growth.

  • HEX #7BB661
  • RGB 123, 182, 97
  • CMYK 32, 0, 47, 29

Cadmium Green

Cadmium Green (#006B3C) is a strong, vivid green originally made from cadmium pigments, known for their opacity and permanence. It emerged with modern chemistry in the 19th century. This pigment is highly toxic but brilliantly stable. The color conveys boldness, artistic intensity, and synthetic vibrancy. Thus, it is prized in artist’s paints, theatrical backdrops, and bold graphic design where maximum impact and lightfastness are required.

  • HEX #006B3C
  • RGB 0, 107, 60
  • CMYK 100, 0, 44, 58

Celadon

Celadon (#ACE1AF) is a pale, grayish-green with a soft blue undertone, named after a type of traditional East Asian ceramic glaze. Historically, it dates back over a thousand years to Chinese and Korean pottery. This color is celebrated for its serene, jade-like quality and subtle elegance. Celadon suggests refinement, tranquility, and ancient artistry. As a result, it is used in luxury product packaging, spa interiors, and wedding themes to evoke calm sophistication.

  • HEX #ACE1AF
  • RGB 172, 225, 175
  • CMYK 24, 0, 22, 12

Celadon Green

Celadon Green (#2F847C) is a stronger, more defined blue-green than Celadon, also derived from ceramic traditions. It represents the more saturated end of the celadon glaze spectrum. This shade carries a cooler, more aquatic feel. It embodies clarity, depth, and artistic heritage. Therefore, Celadon Green is chosen for website design elements, contemporary ceramics, and nautical themes to provide a cultured and refreshing accent.

  • HEX #2F847C
  • RGB 47, 132, 124
  • CMYK 64, 0, 6, 48

Chartreuse

Chartreuse (#DFFF00) is a vibrant yellow-green sitting precisely between yellow and green. It is named after the French liqueur made by Carthusian monks since the 1740s. This color is extremely eye-catching and energetic. Chartreuse represents vivacity, unconventionality, and neon-like glow. Consequently, it is used for high-visibility safety apparel, psychedelic art, and modern tech accents to denote innovation and boldness.

  • HEX #DFFF00
  • RGB 223, 255, 0
  • CMYK 13, 0, 100, 0

China Green

China Green (#C2F732) is a bright, acidic green often associated with the color of greenware in porcelain production. The name references Chinese ceramics, though it’s a modern Western term. This shade is luminous and slightly artificial. It signifies vibrant growth, electric energy, and modern China. Thus, China Green appears in contemporary digital art, advertising, and product design aiming for a futuristic and energetic look.

  • HEX #C2F732
  • RGB 194, 247, 50
  • CMYK 21, 0, 80, 3

Chrome Green

Chrome Green (#2E3A23) is a dark, cool green originally made from chromium oxide pigments, discovered in the early 1800s. It was prized for its chemical stability and opacity. This color is serious, muted, and deeply natural. Chrome Green conveys durability, resilience, and industrial practicality. Therefore, it is common in industrial coatings, military vehicles, and outdoor equipment for its protective and camouflage qualities.

  • HEX #2E3A23
  • RGB 46, 58, 35
  • CMYK 21, 0, 40, 77

Claret Green

Claret Green (#347235) is a medium green with a subtle red wine (claret) undertone, creating a unique, muted earthiness. The name reflects a Victorian descriptive trend combining luxury items. It is a complex and sophisticated shade. Claret Green suggests heritage, richness, and understated luxury. As such, it is used in traditional upholstery, classic wallpaper patterns, and university branding to imply aged prestige.

  • HEX #347235
  • RGB 52, 114, 53
  • CMYK 54, 0, 54, 55

Clover

Clover (#008F00) is a pure, mid-toned green directly named after the leaves of the common clover plant. It is strongly associated with luck, especially the rare four-leaf variety. This color is simple, natural, and universally recognizable. Clover represents fortune, verdant fields, and simple natural beauty. Consequently, it is popular in St. Patrick’s Day themes, gardening logos, and eco-friendly product labels to symbolize luck and nature.

  • HEX #008F00
  • RGB 0, 143, 0
  • CMYK 100, 0, 100, 44

Congo Green

Congo Green (#00A483) is a vivid, bluish-green reminiscent of tropical waters or parrot feathers. The name evokes the lush rainforests of the Congo Basin. It is a rich and exotic shade with high saturation. Congo Green signifies tropical depth, vitality, and vibrant wilderness. Therefore, it is often used in travel industry marketing, tropical prints, and aquatic branding to convey a sense of adventurous luxury and natural splendor.

  • HEX #00A483
  • RGB 0, 164, 131
  • CMYK 100, 0, 20, 36

Cucumber Green

Cucumber Green (#83A96C) is a cool, pale green with strong gray undertones, named for the skin of a cucumber. This color is refreshing, crisp, and subtly cool. It became popular in 1950s kitchen and appliance design. Cucumber Green evokes cool freshness, cleanliness, and mildness. Consequently, it is applied in spa decor, healthcare environments, and product packaging for water or hygiene to suggest a clean, calming experience.

  • HEX #83A96C
  • RGB 131, 169, 108
  • CMYK 22, 0, 36, 34

Dark Green

Dark Green (#013220) is a deep, very dark green approaching black, representing the shadows of dense foliage. It is one of the fundamental and oldest color descriptions. This shade is authoritative, conservative, and natural. Dark Green embodies stability, affluence, and the deep forest. Thus, it is a staple in finance branding, traditional academia, and military uniforms to communicate solidity, wealth, and tradition.

  • HEX #013220
  • RGB 1, 50, 32
  • CMYK 98, 0, 36, 80

Dark Olive Green

Dark Olive Green (#556B2F) is a muted, earthy green with strong brown undertones, akin to a ripe olive. It is a classic military and utilitarian color, standardized for camouflage uniforms. This color is practical, subdued, and naturally concealing. Dark Olive Green suggests resilience, practicality, and a connection to the earth. As a result, it is ubiquitous in workwear, outdoor gear, and rustic interior design for its durable and natural aesthetic.

  • HEX #556B2F
  • RGB 85, 107, 47
  • CMYK 21, 0, 56, 58

Dark Sea Green

Dark Sea Green (#8FBC8F) is a soft, desaturated green with a significant gray influence, reminiscent of ocean depths or mossy stones. It is a web color from early X11 palettes. This shade is calming, muted, and weathered. Dark Sea Green conveys subtlety, tranquility, and natural aging. Therefore, it is frequently used in vintage website themes, coastal interior design, and backgrounds to provide a soft, nondistracting earthy tone.

  • HEX #8FBC8F
  • RGB 143, 188, 143
  • CMYK 24, 0, 24, 26

Dark Spring Green

Dark Spring Green (#177245) is a rich, cool green that captures the deeper tones of new growth in a shaded forest. It is a darker variant of the vibrant Spring Green. This color is lush, cool, and deeply natural. Dark Spring Green symbolizes renewal, abundance, and the mature phase of spring. Consequently, it is effectively used in environmental campaigns, garden center branding, and luxury product packaging to evoke a sense of premium, thriving nature.

  • HEX #177245
  • RGB 23, 114, 69
  • CMYK 80, 0, 39, 55

Deep Green

Deep Green (#056608) is a rich, saturated medium green that represents the essence of greenness at its fullest depth without leaning toward blue or yellow. It is the archetypal, pure mid-green. This color embodies abundance, fertility, and robust health. It is direct and life-affirming. Consequently, Deep Green is a powerful choice for gardening brands, organic supermarket signage, and environmental activism materials.

  • HEX #056608
  • RGB 5, 102, 8
  • CMYK 95, 0, 92, 60

Deep Jungle

Deep Jungle (#004B49) is a very dark, bluish-green that mimics the shadowy depths of a tropical rainforest. The name directly invokes dense, untamed wilderness. This shade is mysterious, rich, and enveloping. Deep Jungle suggests luxuriant growth, secrecy, and adventure. Therefore, it is ideal for mystery novel covers, high-end travel branding, and dramatic wall colors to create an atmosphere of depth and intrigue.

  • HEX #004B49
  • RGB 0, 75, 73
  • CMYK 100, 0, 3, 71

Emerald

Emerald (#50C878) is a bright, vivid green with a cool, bluish bias, named after the precious gemstone. Historically, it has been prized for centuries in jewelry and art. This color is luxurious, radiant, and crisp. Emerald represents wealth, harmony, and dazzling beauty. As a result, it is synonymous with high fashion, jewelry design, and celebratory themes to communicate opulence and vibrant life.

  • HEX #50C878
  • RGB 80, 200, 120
  • CMYK 60, 0, 40, 22

Erin

Erin (#00FF40) is an intense, pure green with a strong yellow undertone. The name is an Anglicization of the Irish word “Éireann,” meaning Ireland. It is a vibrant, almost neon, shade. Erin signifies Irish identity, vivid energy, and unadulterated green. Thus, it is prominently used in digital graphics, national symbolism, and festive decorations to portray maximum brightness and Celtic pride.

  • HEX #00FF40
  • RGB 0, 255, 64
  • CMYK 100, 0, 75, 0

Fern

Fern (#71BC78) is a soft, grayish-green inspired by the fronds of common ferns. This color name became popular during the Arts and Crafts movement which celebrated natural motifs. It is a quiet, soothing, and ubiquitous woodland shade. Fern evokes woodland calm, graceful growth, and natural simplicity. Consequently, it is frequently used in bedroom decor, nature-themed logos, and outdoor apparel to create a serene, organic atmosphere.

  • HEX #71BC78
  • RGB 113, 188, 120
  • CMYK 40, 0, 36, 26

Fern Green

Fern Green (#4F7942) is a darker, more saturated version of Fern, representing the mature, deeper tones of the plant. It is a classic, mid-tone forest green. This shade is grounded, traditional, and deeply natural. Fern Green signifies stability, longevity, and the heart of the forest. Therefore, it is a common choice for national park signage, durable outerwear, and traditional home furnishings to convey reliability and a strong connection to nature.

  • HEX #4F7942
  • RGB 79, 121, 66
  • CMYK 35, 0, 45, 53

Forest Green

Forest Green (#228B22) is a strong, deep green that embodies the color of dense, sun-dappled evergreen trees. It is a standard web color with broad recognition. This color is iconic, robust, and universally associated with woodland. Forest Green represents endurance, natural conservation, and outdoor life. As such, it is fundamental in scouting uniforms, environmental logos, and outdoor product branding to instantly communicate a natural theme.

  • HEX #228B22
  • RGB 34, 139, 34
  • CMYK 76, 0, 76, 45

French Green

French Green (#00755E) is a dark, cool green with a distinct blue undertone, historically known as “Vert de France.” It was popular in French textile and decor during the 18th and 19th centuries. This shade is elegant, refined, and slightly somber. French Green suggests historical luxury, artistic sophistication, and formal gardens. Thus, it is employed in period drama costumes, high-end wallpaper, and museum exhibit design to evoke a sense of European heritage.

  • HEX #00755E
  • RGB 0, 117, 94
  • CMYK 100, 0, 20, 54

Fresh Green

Fresh Green (#69D84F) is a bright, lively yellowish-green that suggests newly sprouted grass. The name directly implies newness and crisp vitality. It is an optimistic and energizing shade. Fresh Green embodies youthful energy, renewal, and eco-innovation. Consequently, it is popular in start-up branding, healthy food packaging, and fitness app interfaces to project a modern, healthy, and dynamic image.

  • HEX #69D84F
  • RGB 105, 216, 79
  • CMYK 51, 0, 63, 15

Granny Smith Apple

Granny Smith Apple (#A8E4A0) is a light, slightly yellowish-green specifically named after the popular tart apple variety. This color captures the crisp, sour, and refreshing quality of the fruit. It became a distinct color reference with global fruit marketing. The shade is clean, zesty, and invigorating. Granny Smith Apple represents healthful tartness, modern freshness, and simple purity. Therefore, it is often used in health food branding, kitchenware design, and spring fashion to convey a crisp, clean feel.

  • HEX #A8E4A0
  • RGB 168, 228, 160
  • CMYK 26, 0, 30, 11

Gray Green

Gray Green (#5E716A) is a muted, desaturated green with a dominant gray tone, resembling weathered stone or lichen. It is a fundamental earth tone found in natural landscapes. This color is subdued, sophisticated, and neutral. Gray Green evokes calmness, timelessness, and organic subtlety. Consequently, it is a favorite in modern interior design, military field gear, and art gallery walls for its quiet, versatile, and elegant backdrop.

  • HEX #5E716A
  • RGB 94, 113, 106
  • CMYK 17, 0, 6, 56

Green Blue

Green Blue (#0D98BA) is a distinct cyan or teal, sitting on the border between green and blue. The name straightforwardly describes its hybrid spectral position. It is a cool, clear, and aquatic color. Green Blue signifies clarity, refreshment, and communicative openness. Thus, it is widely used in social media branding, swimwear lines, and tropical resort advertising to evoke clean water and clear skies.

  • HEX #0D98BA
  • RGB 13, 152, 186
  • CMYK 93, 18, 0, 27

Green Sheen

Green Sheen (#6EAEA1) is a soft, metallic-seeming green with strong gray and blue undertones, reminiscent of tarnished copper or aged patina. The name suggests a lustrous, surface-quality green. This shade is unique, weathered, and elegant. Green Sheen conveys heritage, artifact quality, and subdued luxury. As a result, it is applied in heritage branding, antique restoration, and specialty packaging to suggest age and refined beauty.

  • HEX #6EAEA1
  • RGB 110, 174, 161
  • CMYK 37, 0, 7, 32

Green Yellow

Green Yellow (#ADFF2F) is a bright, fluorescent chartreuse-like color, officially a web color on the spectrum between green and yellow. It is highly luminous and attention-grabbing. This shade embodies electric energy, radioactivity, and synthetic vibrancy. Consequently, Green Yellow is essential for hazard signage, neon fashion accents, and highlighters where maximum visibility and a modern feel are required.

  • HEX #ADFF2F
  • RGB 173, 255, 47
  • CMYK 32, 0, 82, 0

Harlequin Green

Harlequin Green (#46CB18) is a bright, intense green with a slight yellow bias, named after the patterned costume of the Harlequin character from Italian comedy. This color is theatrical, lively, and bold. It represents playfulness, dramatic flair, and vivid festivity. Therefore, Harlequin Green is often used in carnival and festival designs, toy packaging, and performing arts graphics to convey energy and celebration.

  • HEX #46CB18
  • RGB 70, 203, 24
  • CMYK 66, 0, 88, 20

Hooker’s Green

Hooker’s Green (#49796B) is a dark, muted green traditionally made from Prussian Blue and Gamboge, named after botanical illustrator William Hooker. It is a staple color in artist’s watercolor palettes. This shade is naturalistic, deeply muted, and essential for landscape painting. Hooker’s Green suggests botanical accuracy, traditional artistry, and the English countryside. Consequently, it is favored in fine art, heritage branding, and classic print design.

  • HEX #49796B
  • RGB 73, 121, 107
  • CMYK 40, 0, 12, 53

Hunter Green

Hunter Green (#355E3B) is a very dark green with a slight cool undertone, historically associated with 19th-century hunters’ attire for camouflage. It is a classic, formal, and deep green. This color embodies tradition, the great outdoors, and understated wealth. Hunter Green is synonymous with preppy fashion, academic regalia, and luxurious library interiors to communicate heritage and rugged sophistication.

  • HEX #355E3B
  • RGB 53, 94, 59
  • CMYK 44, 0, 37, 63

Ice Green

Ice Green (#87FFCD) is a very pale, cool green with strong blue and white tones, reminiscent of glacial ice or mint frost. It is a cool, ethereal, and almost pastel shade. Ice Green evokes chill, freshness, and pristine clarity. Thus, it is effectively used in winter-themed designs, hygiene product packaging, and spa branding to suggest a clean, cool, and refreshing sensation.

  • HEX #87FFCD
  • RGB 135, 255, 205
  • CMYK 47, 0, 20, 0

India Green

India Green (#138808) is a strong, mid-toned green inspired by the color of the lower band of the Indian national flag. It is a patriotic and culturally significant shade. This green represents fertility, prosperity, and national identity. Consequently, India Green is prominently used in Indian cultural motifs, festival decorations, and products celebrating Indian heritage to symbolize growth and auspiciousness.

  • HEX #138808
  • RGB 19, 136, 8
  • CMYK 86, 0, 94, 47

Inchworm

Inchworm (#B2EC5D) is a bright, yellowish-green named after the color of the common larval insect. It is also a Crayola crayon color introduced in 2003. This shade is playful, vibrant, and slightly neon. Inchworm suggests youthful curiosity, springtime, and whimsical growth. Therefore, it is popular in children’s products, educational materials, and playful website design to evoke fun and natural discovery.

  • HEX #B2EC5D
  • RGB 178, 236, 93
  • CMYK 25, 0, 61, 7

Islamic Green

Islamic Green (#009000) is a pure, medium green historically associated with Islam, mentioned in early Islamic texts and frequently seen in flags of Muslim-majority countries. It is a culturally and religiously significant color. This green symbolizes paradise, faith, and life. Consequently, Islamic Green is used in religious contexts, cultural artifacts, and national symbolism to represent the Islamic faith and heritage.

  • HEX #009000
  • RGB 0, 144, 0
  • CMYK 100, 0, 100, 44

Jade

Jade (#00A86B) is a medium to dark green with a cool, bluish undertone, named after the venerated ornamental stone important in many Asian cultures. This color has been prized for millennia for its beauty and symbolism. Jade represents wisdom, serenity, and good fortune. As such, it is a key color in luxury jewelry design, spa branding, and packaging for high-end products to communicate purity, value, and calm.

  • HEX #00A86B
  • RGB 0, 168, 107
  • CMYK 100, 0, 36, 34

Jungle Green

Jungle Green (#29AB87) is a vibrant, tropical green with a strong cyan influence, directly evoking lush rainforests. It is a Crayola crayon color and a term used in camouflage. This shade is wild, saturated, and energetic. Jungle Green signifies adventure, exotic flora and fauna, and untamed nature. Thus, it is ideal for adventure travel logos, children’s play areas, and vibrant textiles to suggest exploration and vitality.

  • HEX #29AB87
  • RGB 41, 171, 135
  • CMYK 76, 0, 21, 33

Kelly Green

Kelly Green (#4CBB17) is an intense, pure green with a slight yellow bias, often associated with Irish heritage and St. Patrick’s Day. The name likely derives from the common Irish family name. This color is bold, cheerful, and highly visible. Kelly Green represents Irish pride, celebration, and lively exuberance. Consequently, it is ubiquitous in sports team uniforms, festive decorations, and promotional materials for maximum impact.

  • HEX #4CBB17
  • RGB 76, 187, 23
  • CMYK 59, 0, 88, 27

Khaki Green

Khaki Green (#8A865D) is a dull, yellowish-brown with a strong green undertone, originating from the Persian word for “dust.” It is the original color of military field uniforms from the 19th century. This shade is utilitarian, neutral, and naturally camouflaging. Khaki Green suggests practicality, endurance, and a rugged outdoor lifestyle. Therefore, it remains fundamental in military apparel, safari clothing, and casual workwear for its functional and earthy quality.

  • HEX #8A865D
  • RGB 138, 134, 93

La Salle Green

  • HEX #C6FF00
  • RGB 198, 255, 0
  • CMYK 22, 0, 100, 0

Kelly Lime

Kelly Lime (#B1DD52) is a vibrant, yellowish-green that blends the pure intensity of Kelly Green with the zest of Lime. It is a custom, high-energy hybrid shade. This color embodies festive athleticism, tropical punch, and modern exuberance. Consequently, Kelly Lime is found in sports team alternates, summer beverage advertising, and lively web design to create a uniquely energetic and friendly vibe.

  • HEX #B1DD52
  • RGB 177, 221, 82
  • CMYK 20, 0, 63, 13

Shamrock Lime

Shamrock Lime (#45CE95) is a bright, cyan-leaning green that merges the cultural resonance of Shamrock with the freshness of Lime. It is a lucky, vibrant, and refreshing tone. Shamrock Lime suggests modern Irish pride, sparkling freshness, and celebratory energy. Therefore, it is used in contemporary St. Patrick’s Day designs, eco-friendly product lines, and vibrant app icons for a fresh take on tradition.

  • HEX #45CE95
  • RGB 69, 206, 149
  • CMYK 67, 0, 28, 19

Emerald Isle

Emerald Isle (#019875) is a rich, deep green directly named after the poetic nickname for Ireland. It is a verdant, lush, and culturally evocative shade. This color represents Irish landscape mythology, deep natural beauty, and romantic heritage. As a result, Emerald Isle is employed in tourist advertising for Ireland, cultural products, and literary publications to instantly evoke the lush, green imagery of Ireland.

  • HEX #019875
  • RGB 1, 152, 117
  • CMYK 99, 0, 23, 40
